a: A target is referred to as the unique domain address of a website, defined by its name or IP, protocol (e.g., HTTP/HTTPS), and port (e.g., 80/8080). For example, `https://app.domain.com `and `https://docs.domain.com` are considered distinct domains because they use different subdomains (app vs. docs), even though they share the same base domain (domain.com). This distinction allows ZeroThreat to treat them as separate entities for scanning purposes.

q: How do I add a target in ZeroThreat?
a: Navigate to the Targets page, click 'Add Target,' input the web app URL (e.g.,` https://app.example.com`), select a scanning server, assign it to an organization, and save. This sets up your scan starting point.

q: What exactly counts as a host or target in ZeroThreat (IP, domain, subdomain)?
a: In ZeroThreat, a host (target) refers to any unique IP address, domain, or subdomain that is scanned for vulnerabilities. Each distinct entry is considered a separate host.

q: If I scan subdomains, does each subdomain count as a separate target?
a: Yes, each subdomain is treated as a separate target and will count individually for scanning and reporting purposes.

q: How do I verify a target?
a: Go to Targets, click 'Verify Now,' and choose either uploading a provided HTML file to your site’s root or adding a DNS TXT record via your provider. After setup, click 'Verify' to confirm. Check Docs for a detailed step-by-step guide.

Target configuration customizes scan settings like server location, technology stack, authentication templates, allowed hosts, and ignored URIs. It ensures scans align with your app’s specifics for more accurate and relevant results.
An additional target refers to a new domain, subdomain, or IP address added to your existing account for scanning. It allows you to extend your security coverage to other assets.

Specifying the app’s tech stack (e.g., PHP, ASP.NET) ensures ZeroThreat provides accurate analysis and tailored remediation. This customization enhances scan effectiveness, executive summary and makes the remediation for developers more convenient.

q: How do I add custom headers?
a: Go to Targets, select your target, navigate to Request Headers in configuration, choose a request target, enter a key (e.g., 'access_token') and value, then save. This applies to all scan requests for that target. Check Docs for detailed step-by-step guide.

By default, a target includes all URLs within its domain, such as `https://example.com/blogs` from `https://example.com/dashboard`. To add external domains, like `payments.thirdparty.com`, go to the Targets section, locate the target, and click the gear icon to open the configuration drawer. Enter the external hosts in the Allowed Hosts section. This ensures ZeroThreat scans all related resources for a complete security assessment.
